Expectation1: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation1: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: The main protest march is beginning in a few minutes, and you are needed at the front to lead the first chant.
Story: I glance at the clock in the lab, my hands trembling as I double-check the setup for the experiment. The data I could gather today would be crucial for my research, and I know my advisor expects me to be thorough and focused. But my phone buzzes again—messages from fellow activists, reminding me that the protest march is about to start. They’re counting on me to lead the first chant, to be the face at the front, rallying everyone together. I can hear the distant hum of voices gathering outside, the energy building. I know the experiment can wait; there are other slots, and missing this one won’t derail my project. But I also know how important it is to keep momentum in the lab, to show commitment. My heart pounds as I weigh the sterile calm of the lab against the urgent call of the street. I feel pulled in two, the expectations of my colleagues and my cause pressing in from both sides, and I stand frozen, unable to move, caught between the world of data and the world of voices demanding change.
